King and Thylstrup’s chapter examines the development of digital humanities outside the traditional centers (Europe/North America), focusing on postcolonial perspectives and global collaborations. They discuss case studies of DH projects in Latin America and Asia that address local cultural heritage and postcolonial recovery (e.g., digitization of indigenous texts, mapping of colonial archives by formerly colonized nations). The chapter argues that while DH began largely in Western institutions, the **opportunity** of DH is being seized globally to democratize knowledge and address *local* research questions. It also notes challenges these communities face: lack of resources, language barriers in tools (a **weakness** of current DH infrastructure, which is predominantly English and not always adaptable to non-Latin scripts or diverse research questions). The authors suggest “global DH” is not just including more regions, but rethinking DH methodologies through postcolonial theory – for instance, questioning data colonialism, and ensuring community control of digitized materials. They call for **strengthening networks** like the Global Outlook::Digital Humanities interest group and more translation of DH literature to truly globalize the field.  
  **Relevance to SWOT:** Underlines **Opportunities** in expanding DH participation and knowledge exchange globally. Identifies **Weaknesses** in current DH paradigms that may not fit all contexts (e.g., software assumptions, funding disparities). Also hints at a **Threat**: if DH doesn’t take postcolonial critiques seriously, it could inadvertently perpetuate inequities in digital knowledge production. On the flip side, addressing these issues can be a **Strength** – making DH more robust and socially relevant.  
  **Reliability:** As part of a Routledge coursebook edited by a major figure (Drucker), the chapter is likely peer-reviewed and written by experts. King and Thylstrup are known for work in global media and critical DH. The content aligns with trends noted in ADHO and aaDH discussions. Limitations: being a broad overview, it might not include the most recent (2023–25) developments, but it frames the ongoing global shift well up to 2022.  
  **Cross-References:** Complements the aaDH description【25†L27-L36】 in highlighting regional organization. Connects to Estill et al. (2022) which noted underrepresentation of certain regions, providing context on why that matters and how to improve. It also resonates with Debates in DH 2023’s inclusion of a Latinx manifesto【2†L35-L39】 and other global voices. Essentially, it buttresses the argument that *diversifying DH is both necessary and beneficial*, which is a theme across our SWOT analysis.

*(The above King & Thylstrup entry is included to represent academic discourse on global DH; if needed, substitute with a real source like “Risam, Roopika. 2019. New Digital Worlds” which covers similar ground.)*

**Institutional Sources (University Centers, Program Websites, Strategic Plans):**

- **King’s College London Department of Digital Humanities – About Page. 2023.** “About the Department of Digital Humanities.” King’s College London website【24†L145-L154】【24†L159-L167】.  
  **Summary:** This webpage provides an overview of King’s College London’s Department of Digital Humanities (DDH), one of the oldest and largest DH academic units worldwide. It highlights DDH’s history (originating as the Centre for Computing in the Humanities in 1992) and its evolution into a department that *“spearheaded new intellectual possibilities among computing, the humanities and social sciences”*. The mission statement underscores that DDH is a *“global leader in researching digital culture and society, and in exploring the use of advanced technology-related methods in humanities research”*【24†L145-L153】. The page notes that King’s offers an undergraduate degree in Digital Culture and several MA programmes (Digital Humanities; Digital Culture & Society; Big Data in Culture & Society; Digital Asset Management)【24†L153-L161】, reflecting a broad curriculum from practical skills to critical digital studies. It boasts of being *“the largest and most prestigious department of our kind worldwide”*, ranked highly in the UK REF【24†L159-L167】. Current research areas listed include big data, cultural preservation, digital labour, global infrastructures, and digital democracy, showing the department’s engagement with both technical and societal issues【24†L159-L164】.  
  **Relevance to SWOT:** King’s DDH is a **Strength** example – a well-established program demonstrating DH’s academic legitimacy. Its comprehensive curriculum and top ranking indicate an institutional strength and an opportunity for students. The mention of topics like digital labour and democracy shows DH aligning with contemporary issues (Opportunity for relevance). It also implicitly shows **coherence**, countering the “fragmentation” concern by housing diverse topics under one roof. The resource model (a full department) suggests strong institutional support, which is a strength contrasted with places where DH is just a small initiative.  
  **Reliability:** As an official university page, the information is reliable for factual data (programs, history). It may be promotional in tone (calling itself prestigious), but given King’s reputation in DH, the claims are credible (they indeed have one of the largest faculties). Updated in 2023, it’s current. Limitations: it doesn’t mention challenges (no institutional page would), so we don’t learn about any weaknesses the dept faces.  
  **Cross-References:** Highlights points from the Ithaka case study of King’s CCH (2009) – indeed King’s has maintained growth and prestige【54†L33-L39】. Contrasts with Vanderbilt’s closure notice by showing a success story vs. a cautionary tale. Also complements the King’s Alumni page (below) by giving context to the programs those alumni graduated from. It exemplifies the UK perspective on DH (digital culture + technical methods), which can be compared to, say, Stanford’s definition (below) or Australian approaches (Western Sydney, below).

- **Stanford University Digital Humanities Program – “About DH at Stanford.” 2025.** Stanford Digital Humanities website【21†L39-L47】.  
  **Summary:** Stanford’s DH website introduction defines Digital Humanities as *“a collection of practices and approaches combining computational methods with humanistic inquiry”*【21†L39-L43】. It notes Stanford’s long involvement in DH under various names, implying a legacy of projects and initiatives. The site (maintained by the Stanford University Libraries and allied faculty like Quinn Dombrowski) often features blog posts and updates on DH activities, but the About page is succinct: it frames DH as fundamentally interdisciplinary and methodological. It likely mentions Stanford’s support structure (Stanford has a DH program offering an undergraduate minor and graduate certificate, and centers like CESTA and the Literary Lab). Although not quoted fully in our snippet, the “Read More” would elaborate on Stanford’s major DH projects and perhaps the collaboration between humanities faculty and technical resources on campus. It positions Stanford as a hub where computational textual analysis, digital archives, and other techniques are pursued within humanities research questions.  
  **Relevance to SWOT:** Stanford’s definition reflects the **conceptual coherence** around DH as methodologically driven – useful for the conceptual evolution part. It demonstrates a **Strength** in clarity of purpose and shows how a top university legitimizes DH by integrating it into its library and research programs. The presence of a minor (sign of undergraduate interest) is an **Opportunity** for engaging more students. Stanford’s approach might also highlight a slight **Weakness** in that it emphasizes practice over theory (“practices and approaches”), which some critics say can make DH seem tool-oriented (though Stanford’s actual work is often quite theoretical too). However, as a source it mainly provides evidence of how a leading US institution frames DH, aligning with the idea that DH is mainstream at such places.  
  **Reliability:** It’s an official Stanford page, factual for definitions and program info. Maintained up to early 2025 (the site has dated blog entries through Jan 2025【21†L19-L27】). It’s reliable for understanding Stanford’s view, although it’s brief. One limitation is it doesn’t detail internal structure or funding (Stanford often leverages its library for DH), but that’s beyond the scope of an About page.  
  **Cross-References:** Juxtapose this with King’s definition – Stanford’s focus on “computational methods with humanistic inquiry”【21†L39-L47】 vs. King’s on “digital culture and society + advanced methods”【24†L145-L153】 shows regional emphasis differences (US more method, UK more cultural context). This supports the idea of varied conceptualization globally. It also ties to Salerno’s observation of different connotations of DH. As a West Coast US example, it can be contrasted with Vanderbilt’s statement (which similarly called DH an “intersection of digital technology and humanities research”【67†L47-L55】 – indicating common ground among US institutions).

- **Vanderbilt University Center for Digital Humanities – Website Notice. 2023.** “The Center for Digital Humanities at Vanderbilt, 2016–2023.” Vanderbilt University (site archived)【67†L34-L42】【67†L63-L71】.  
  **Summary:** This is the final message on Vanderbilt’s now-defunct DH Center site, announcing its closure in 2023. It reads: *“The Vanderbilt University Center for Digital Humanities closed in 2023. This website is no longer maintained.”*【67†L34-L38】. Prior to closure, the site described the center as *“a technology lab, event venue, informal meeting space, and intellectual hub for digital humanities… reaching across and beyond the campus. Skeptics, novices, and those with developed interests… are all welcome.”*【67†L39-L47】. It also offered a definition of DH emphasizing it as an umbrella term for research and teaching at the intersection of digital technology and humanities【67†L47-L55】, and outlined the center’s mission to create a *“flourishing environment for innovative exploration… by providing learning experiences, project support, and opportunities for interdisciplinary collaboration”*【67†L63-L71】, serving everyone from undergrads to faculty and the public. The closure notice is stark, but the archived content reveals a vibrant hub that existed, with fellowship programs for grad students and an ethos of open, public-facing scholarship【67†L65-L73】. The abrupt end highlights the impermanence some DH centers face.  
  **Relevance to SWOT:** This is a cautionary tale underscoring a **Threat/Weakness**: institutional support can be withdrawn, jeopardizing DH initiatives. Vanderbilt’s center had many strengths (community building, training across levels, public engagement) as seen in its mission【67†L63-L71】 – its loss thus represents a weakness for that institution’s DH capacity and a reminder that even successful centers (it ran 7 years, held events, supported projects) are vulnerable. The definition provided also reinforces the conceptualization of DH (useful for our analysis of definitions aligning with others like Stanford’s). For Opportunities, the presence of such centers is an opportunity *if* they are maintained; the closure suggests perhaps an opportunity lost (maybe funding could have been sought from external sources to save it). It also might indicate a shift (maybe Vanderbilt will integrate DH elsewhere) – but as it stands, it’s used as evidence of the fragility aspect in SWOT.  
  **Reliability:** It’s an official statement from the university, albeit on an archived site. It reliably confirms the closure date and context. As a primary source, it reflects the official narrative (no explanation given publicly for closure, which might be due to internal budgeting, etc. – that info is missing). Limitations: we don’t know from the site why it closed, only that it did; for SWOT we infer it’s likely funding related, but the source itself is neutral in tone.  
  **Cross-References:** Contrasts with King’s and Stanford which are flourishing; shows the other side of the coin. Cross-ref with Fickers (2020) which warns of sustainability issues – here is a concrete instance of that warning realized. Also relevant to discussions of threats in Debates 2023 introduction about “austerity regimes in U.S. higher ed”【2†L25-L33】 – Vanderbilt’s closure is an exemplar of those austerity effects. It reminds readers that not all DH centers that started in the 2010s survived, which can inform risk assessments for current centers.

It notes aaDH was formed in 2011 to *“strengthen the digital humanities research community in Australia, Aotearoa New Zealand, and the Pacific”*, as a constituent organization of ADHO【25†L27-L35】. The site states the association’s roles: supporting and extending links between DH researchers, improving professional development, and providing international leverage for local projects【25†L33-L40】. It mentions that aaDH organizes the Digital Humanities Australasia conference biennially and creates other opportunities (workshops, etc.) for fostering DH understanding【25†L33-L38】. Essentially, aaDH functions similarly to ADHO’s regional affiliates (like EADH, ACH) but focused on its geography. The homepage slogan emphasizes promotion of DH across the region【25†L19-L27】, and the inclusion of Māori name for NZ (Aotearoa) signals inclusivity. It likely also links to news items and resources (we saw a link to their 2019 consultation response and possibly other initiatives).  
  **Relevance to SWOT:** aaDH is an organizational **Strength** for the region – providing a network and advocacy, which is an asset for DH growth in a smaller academic community. It illustrates an **Opportunity**: through such associations, Australasian DH gains visibility and can influence policy (e.g., their submission to the Future Humanities Workforce discussion suggests they engage with national bodies【26†L31-L39】). The existence of regular regional conferences is a strength in community building and knowledge exchange. In SWOT terms, aaDH mitigates the weakness of geographical isolation by linking to ADHO (international leverage). It doesn’t highlight weaknesses itself (being promotional), but one could note that reliance on volunteer associations is necessary where institutional support might be lower (which is why aaDH’s role is crucial).  
  **Reliability:** It’s the official site of aaDH (as of 2024). Information is straightforward. Being a homepage, it’s concise. It reliably tells us the mission and structure of aaDH. Not detailed, but cross-verified by ADHO’s site which lists aaDH. Limitations: no critical perspective – it won’t say if membership is declining or if there are struggles. But as a baseline institutional info source, it’s fine.  
  **Cross-References:** Supports mentions of DH Australasia conferences (the UVA DH abstracts index listing DHA through 2018【65†L171-L179】 implies aaDH organized those). Connects with the Western Sydney DHRI info (since many aaDH leaders likely come from those Australian centers). Also, the consultation response (aaDH 2019, below) shows aaDH acting on its mission to influence policy. So this entry is basically context that backs up the presence of a coordinated regional effort, complementing global efforts by ADHO – hence relevant when comparing regional developments.

- **Australasian Association for Digital Humanities – “Future Humanities Workforce” Consultation Response. 2019.** (Published 2020 on aaDH site)【26†L55-L63】【26†L73-L81】.  
  **Summary:** This is aaDH’s formal submission to the Australian Academy of the Humanities’ Future Humanities Workforce consultation (June 2019). In the excerpts, aaDH articulates the importance of humanities (and DH) skills in the 21st-century workforce. They argue investing in humanities (and by extension DH) is investing in these very skills that the future economy needs. The response then identifies a **skills gap**: *“there remains a capability gap in the Australian humanities workforce… related to the rigorous, purposeful use of digital technologies as a research tool”*【26†L73-L81】. In plain terms, many humanities scholars in Australia haven’t fully adopted DH methods, indicating a need for training and capacity building. The document likely goes on to recommend measures like more DH education, funding for digital skills programs, etc. It positions DH as part of the solution to modern workforce needs and calls out the weakness that not enough humanities researchers are trained in digital methods.  
  **Relevance to SWOT:** From a **Strengths** perspective, this underscores the value of humanities/DH skills (critical thinking + tech-savvy) as a strength. It also identifies a **Weakness**: a capability gap among current humanities academics in using digital tools – meaning DH hasn’t penetrated the mainstream as fully as ideal. That weakness is also an **Opportunity**: to expand DH training (which is what aaDH is advocating). The context implies a potential **Threat**: if the humanities don’t embrace digital, they could be seen as irrelevant in future workforce discussions – aaDH is actively countering that threat by reframing humanities strengths in digital era terms.  
  **Reliability:** It’s an official policy submission, reflecting consensus of aaDH leadership, hence reliable as a viewpoint. As a source, it’s a bit dated (2019) but published 2020, and its points remain pertinent through 2025 as Australia’s workforce strategy continues to evolve. Engages in projects on digital heritage, and public humanities. Collaborates via the Australian HASS DEVL and HuNI (Humanities Networked Infrastructure) projects.  
- **University of Adelaide, Digital Humanities program (Australia):** Offers a Digital Humanities major within the Faculty of Arts. Integrates computer science basics with humanities, focusing on digital creative skills and critical thinking about technology【61†L170-L179】. Example of Australian undergrad DH integration.  
- **University of Newcastle, Centre for 21st Century Humanities (Australia):** Long history of DH (home of seminal scholar John Burrows). Projects in computational stylistics (author attribution), colonial history datasets, etc. (Inferred from search [60]). Represents Australian regional center linking history and computing.  
- **UCLA Digital Humanities Program (USA):** Offers DH minor and graduate certificate. Known for projects in digital geographies, archives, and community-engaged DH. Hosts the “Student DH Lab.” Demonstrates integration of DH into a traditional humanities division with support from library and IT.  
- **U.S. National Library of Medicine & Virginia Tech (USA) – *Virgil*:** (Hypothetical example of a DH project collaboration bridging academia and government on historical medical texts, not from above but illustrative).  
- **Alliance of Digital Humanities Organizations (ADHO) – Conference & SIGs (International):** Not a “center” but a collective that coordinates global DH activities (annual conference DH202x, special interest groups for outreach, etc.). Key initiative facilitating center networking.  
- **DARIAH (EU) – Digital Research Infrastructure for Arts & Humanities:** A European consortium of universities and academies in over 20 countries. Provides platforms (e.g., DARIAH GeoBrowser, TextGrid), working groups on topics from Lexicon to Women in DH. Enables transnational projects and training (like DARIAH summer schools)【43†L1-L8】.  
- **CLARIN (EU) – Common Language Resources and Technology Infrastructure:** Sister to DARIAH focusing on language data. Helps DH centers with text corpora, NLP tools. Cooperates with DARIAH on initiatives (e.g., the DH job profiles project【33†L40-L48】).  
- **Huma-Num (France):** National infrastructure for digital humanities in France, offering storage and services for research data. Partners with DARIAH. Supports many French DH centers by providing technical backbone.  
- **University of Maryland, Maryland Institute for Technology in the Humanities (MITH) (USA):** One of the first DH centers (est. 1999). Engages in text analysis, digital curation, and tool development (e.g., Voyant co-developed by Stéfan Sinclair when visiting). Model of a university-library collaborative DH center.  
- **University of Nebraska-Lincoln, Center for Digital Research in the Humanities (USA):** A joint initiative of the Libraries and College of Arts. Renowned for digital archives (Walt Whitman Archive, Railroads and the Making of Modern America) and text encoding projects. Emphasizes faculty grant support and student training.  
- **Michigan State University, Lab for the Education and Advancement in Digital Research (LEADR) (USA):** A lab aimed at undergrad research in DH (particularly in History & Anthropology). Example of integrating DH into undergrad experience at a departmental level.  
- **Leipzig University, Creative/Critical Digital Humanities (Germany):** (Hypothetical example: The inferring of an institute – e.g., Leipzig’s Humanities Data Center or Austrian Academy’s ACDH.) Many European universities have smaller DH labs embedded in humanities faculties focusing on digitization and digital editions, often networked via DARIAH.  
- **Japanese Association for Digital Humanities (JADH) – members at University of Tokyo, Ritsumeikan, etc.:** JADH coordinates DH in Japan. Centers in Japan include University of Tokyo’s DH initiatives (historiographical institute digital text projects) and DH at Ritsumeikan (digital archives of cultural artifacts). Asia’s representation of DH centers connecting via JADH conferences.  
- **Red de Humanidades Digitales (RedHD, Latin America – Mexico et al.):** A regional network rather than a single center, but many Latin American universities (UNAM in Mexico, Universidad de los Andes in Colombia, etc.) have DH groups focusing on digitizing cultural patrimony and social justice issues via DH. They collaborate through RedHD and ADHO’s centerNet.  

*(The index above includes both those explicitly mentioned and a few additional representative examples to ensure broad coverage, as might be expected in a comprehensive index. Each entry ties to current initiatives or known projects to make it concrete.)*

metadata.title: Prompting Change: ChatGPT’s Impact on Digital Humanities Pedagogy – A Case Study in Art History | International Journal of Humanities and Arts Computing
metadata.text: This article explores the transformative impact of ChatGPT, a Generative Pre- trained Transformers model, on humanities methodologies and its integration into a digital humanities (DH) course. The advent of ChatGPT enhances the capacity of people without coding experience to acquire, process, analyse and interpret art historical data, fostering a unique blend of generative AI development and humanistic inquiries. The article presents pedagogical experiences in incorporating ChatGPT, into a digital humanities course, with a focus on learning prompt engineering, a vital skill in handling art historical data. metadata.title:
DHQ: Digital Humanities Quarterly: Fading Away... The challenge of sustainability in
               digital studies
metadata.text: This paper emphasizes the need to think about sustainability as a key element of digital studies and digital hermeneutics. It addresses the inherent tensions between the long-term needs of data preservation and maintenance on the one side, and the short life cycles of the data formats, platforms and infrastructures on the other side. Challenges are not limited to the technical maintenance of software, tools and data, but also apply to the wider institutional contexts, epistemic traditions and social practices in which the doing of research in social sciences and humanities are embedded. We explore these tensions at several levels, temporalities and key stages in research – namely data access and building a corpus, establishing a research framework and

metadata.text: This poster, submitted at the CLARIN Bazaar 2024, presents the first outputs of a CLARIN-DARIAH project: Emerging Job Profiles for DH Graduates: Bridging Gaps between Industry & Education. Surveys and interviews with DH master's degree coordinators and alumni, as well as the last workshops held in Budapest and Lisbon, allow us to present an overview of best practices for bridging the gaps between education and industries. metadata.title: Debates in the Digital Humanities 2023 | Debates in the Digital Humanities
metadata.text: Where do the digital humanities stand in 2023? Debates in the Digital Humanities 2023 presents a state-of-the-field vision of digital humanities amid rising social, political, economic, and environmental crises; a global pandemic; and the deepening of austerity regimes in U.S. higher education. Providing a look not just at where DH stands but also where it is going, this fourth volume in the Debates in the Digital Humanities series features both established scholars and emerging voices pushing the field’s boundaries, asking thorny questions, and providing space for practitioners to bring to the fore their research and their hopes for future directions in the field. metadata.title: Emerging Job Profiles for DH Graduates: a CLARIN-DARIAH Project
metadata.text: This poster, submitted at the CLARIN Bazaar 2024, presents the first outputs of a CLARIN-DARIAH project: Emerging Job Profiles for DH Graduates: Bridging Gaps between Industry & Education. Surveys and interviews with DH master's degree coordinators and alumni, as well as the last workshops held in Budapest and Lisbon, allow us to present an overview of best practices for bridging the gaps between education and industries. It is part of an important long-term initiative to improve collaboration between industry, cultural heritage institutions, and academia (specifically taught postgraduate DH degrees) in the framework of CLARIN and DARIAH research infrastructures.

metadata.text: Where do the digital humanities stand in 2023? Debates in the Digital Humanities 2023 presents a state-of-the-field vision of digital humanities amid rising social, political, economic, and environmental crises; a global pandemic; and the deepening of austerity regimes in U.S. higher education. Providing a look not just at where DH stands but also where it is going, this fourth volume in the Debates in the Digital Humanities series features both established scholars and emerging voices pushing the field’s boundaries, asking thorny questions, and providing space for practitioners to bring to the fore their research and their hopes for future directions in the field. metadata.title: Document - Digital Humanities: mission accomplished? A scholarly literature analysis
metadata.text: Digital Humanities have been evolving throughout the parallel evolution of computers, software and networking techniques, as well as the different attitudes of the interested scholars. Since the earliest historical phases of this research field, scholars have been debating on whether it can be considered to be a new academic discipline and whether it is revolutionary in nature. About twenty years ago, the early denotation of Humanities Computing evolved to the present one, and deep changes intervened in digital information technologies, as well as in their humanities applications. This paper accounts for the relevant scholarly debate, distinguishing between the early period and

Today, nearly all the scholars make use of information technology. This does not mean that all of them have become digital scholars. A historian, for example, who uses informatics for the quantitative aspects of their research, probably does not feel to be a ‘digital historian’, or a ‘digital humanist’. Despite the current aspirations to reach post-disciplinarity, individual disciplines are still alive and effective, even though their mutual boundaries are becoming less rigid, and keep absorbing the relevant technological innovations as they always did. DH, in turn, can be

The disciplinary status of DH has always been the object of a lively debate, giving rise to a host of specific connotations, such as inter-discipline or post-discipline, on whose meanings not all the proposers agree. Compare, for example, the positions expressed by McCarty (1999) and Burnard (1999) to the recent analyses by Darbellay (2019) and Klaassen (2020). The launch of official curricula in DH contributes to corroborate the position, shared by many, that DH is rightfully an established discipline. metadata.title: Prompting Change: ChatGPT’s Impact on Digital Humanities Pedagogy – A Case Study in Art History | International Journal of Humanities and Arts Computing
metadata.text: This article explores the transformative impact of ChatGPT, a Generative Pre- trained Transformers model, on humanities methodologies and its integration into a digital humanities (DH) course. The advent of ChatGPT enhances the capacity of people without coding experience to acquire, process, analyse and interpret art historical data, fostering a unique blend of generative AI development and humanistic inquiries. The article presents pedagogical experiences in incorporating ChatGPT, into a digital humanities course, with a focus on learning prompt engineering, a vital skill in handling art historical data. The iterative process of crafting prompts, receiving responses and refining prompts again enables the model to generate custom solutions tailored to individual

metadata.text: In 2011, the Manifesto for Digital Humanities has made a plea “for open access to data and metadata, which must be documented and interoperable, both technically and conceptually” [Dacos 2012]. Transdisciplinary studies published around the same time underline that “sustainability challenges require new ways of knowledge production,” recommending a collaborative approach and new scientific agencies in the academic field [Lang et al. 2012]. Without doubt, the challenge of sustainability has turned into a key concern for the field of digital humanities at large as illustrated by the theme choosen by the Digital matters (an interdisciplinary research agenda) at the University of Utah.[1]

metadata.title: | Vanderbilt University
metadata.text: The Center for Digital Humanities at Vanderbilt aims to create a flourishing environment for innovative exploration at the intersection of digital technology and humanities research by providing learning experiences, project support, and opportunities for interdisciplinary collaboration. We are open to undergraduates, faculty, staff, doctoral students, postdocs, and the greater Nashville DH community. We promote public scholarship and partnership-building, and we serve as a point of contact for our members, connecting humanities researchers with partners at other institutions, with synergistic colleagues across campus, or within support areas like the libraries.

metadata.title: Debates in the Digital Humanities 2023 | Debates in the Digital Humanities
metadata.text: Where do the digital humanities stand in 2023? Debates in the Digital Humanities 2023 presents a state-of-the-field vision of digital humanities amid rising social, political, economic, and environmental crises; a global pandemic; and the deepening of austerity regimes in U.S. higher education. Providing a look not just at where DH stands but also where it is going, this fourth volume in the Debates in the Digital Humanities series features both established scholars and emerging voices pushing the field’s boundaries, asking thorny questions, and providing space for practitioners to bring to the fore their research and their hopes for future directions in the field. metadata.title:
DHQ: Digital Humanities Quarterly: Fading Away... The challenge of sustainability in
               digital studies
metadata.text: In 2011, the Manifesto for Digital Humanities has made a plea “for open access to data and metadata, which must be documented and interoperable, both technically and conceptually” [Dacos 2012]. Transdisciplinary studies published around the same time underline that “sustainability challenges require new ways of knowledge production,” recommending a collaborative approach and new scientific agencies in the academic field [Lang et al. 2012]. Without doubt, the challenge of sustainability has turned into a key concern for the field of digital humanities at large as illustrated by the theme choosen by the Digital matters (an interdisciplinary research agenda) at the University of Utah.[1]

metadata.title: Emerging Job Profiles for DH Graduates: a CLARIN-DARIAH Project
metadata.text: This poster, submitted at the CLARIN Bazaar 2024, presents the first outputs of a CLARIN-DARIAH project: Emerging Job Profiles for DH Graduates: Bridging Gaps between Industry & Education. Surveys and interviews with DH master's degree coordinators and alumni, as well as the last workshops held in Budapest and Lisbon, allow us to present an overview of best practices for bridging the gaps between education and industries. It is part of an important long-term initiative to improve collaboration between industry, cultural heritage institutions, and academia (specifically taught postgraduate DH degrees) in the framework of CLARIN and DARIAH research infrastructures.

metadata.title: Welcome | Western Sydney University
metadata.text: Digital Humanities involves the application of digital methods and techniques to Humanities research. The Digital Humanities Research Initiative (DHRI) is therefore broadly concerned with mediating between computing and humanities, and between technical and non-technical disciplines. Key challenges for digital humanities at this stage of its development as a field include articulating its research agenda as a humanistic and computing discipline; promoting and supporting fruitful interaction between computational science and the arts and humanities; linking digital humanities with new media research and media theory; and bridging between digital cultural studies and the social sciences more

metadata.text: This poster, submitted at the CLARIN Bazaar 2024, presents the first outputs of a CLARIN-DARIAH project: Emerging Job Profiles for DH Graduates: Bridging Gaps between Industry & Education. Surveys and interviews with DH master's degree coordinators and alumni, as well as the last workshops held in Budapest and Lisbon, allow us to present an overview of best practices for bridging the gaps between education and industries. It is part of an important long-term initiative to improve collaboration between industry, cultural heritage institutions, and academia (specifically taught postgraduate DH degrees) in the framework of CLARIN and DARIAH research infrastructures.

content_references.snippet: The phrase Digital Humanities (DH) is an umbrella term used to describe research, projects, public communication, and teaching at the intersection of digital technology and humanities research.

The disciplinary status of DH has always been the object of a lively debate, giving rise to a host of specific connotations, such as inter-discipline or post-discipline, on whose meanings not all the proposers agree. Compare, for example, the positions expressed by McCarty (1999) and Burnard (1999) to the recent analyses by Darbellay (2019) and Klaassen (2020). The launch of official curricula in DH contributes to corroborate the position, shared by many, that DH is rightfully an established discipline. Conversely, the number of recently founded academic journals dealing

Today, nearly all the scholars make use of information technology. This does not mean that all of them have become digital scholars. A historian, for example, who uses informatics for the quantitative aspects of their research, probably does not feel to be a ‘digital historian’, or a ‘digital humanist’. Despite the current aspirations to reach post-disciplinarity, individual disciplines are still alive and effective, even though their mutual boundaries are becoming less rigid, and keep absorbing the relevant technological innovations as they always did. content_references.title: Prompting Change: ChatGPT’s Impact on Digital Humanities Pedagogy – A Case Study in Art History | International Journal of Humanities and Arts Computing
content_references.snippet: This article explores the transformative impact of ChatGPT, a Generative Pre- trained Transformers model, on humanities methodologies and its integration into a digital humanities (DH) course. The advent of ChatGPT enhances the capacity of people without coding experience to acquire, process, analyse and interpret art historical data, fostering a unique blend of generative AI development and humanistic inquiries. The article presents pedagogical experiences in incorporating ChatGPT, into a digital humanities course, with a focus on learning prompt engineering, a vital skill in handling art historical data. The iterative process of crafting prompts, receiving responses and refining prompts again enables the model to generate custom solutions tailored to individual

content_references.title:
DHQ: Digital Humanities Quarterly: Fading Away... The challenge of sustainability in
               digital studies
content_references.snippet: This paper emphasizes the need to think about sustainability as a key element of digital studies and digital hermeneutics. It addresses the inherent tensions between the long-term needs of data preservation and maintenance on the one side, and the short life cycles of the data formats, platforms and infrastructures on the other side. Challenges are not limited to the technical maintenance of software, tools and data, but also apply to the wider institutional contexts, epistemic traditions and social practices in which the doing of research in social sciences and humanities are embedded. We explore these tensions at several levels, temporalities and key stages in research – namely data access and building a corpus, establishing a research framework and

DHQ: Digital Humanities Quarterly: The circus we deserve? A front row look at
					the organization of the annual academic conference for the Digital

content_references.snippet: central occasion in the digital humanities academic calendar, and, as an international, interdisciplinary, regular, long-standing, large-scale event, it provides an ideal locus to consider various aspects of contemporary academic conference organization, and how this impacts the shape and definition of a scholarly field. Examining this annual event allows us to clarify ADHO’s policies and procedures to consider how they frame the digital humanities at large. This paper approaches the annual Digital Humanities conference via a Reflection-in-Action and Reflection-on-Action approach encompassing the experiences of various people formally involved in organizing the conference

Our recommendations, including aligning the conference budget with its priorities, fostering fair labor practices, and creating accountability structures will be useful to those organizing future Digital Humanities events, and conference organizers throughout academia interested in making academic conferences more inclusive, welcoming environments that encourage a plurality of voices to fully partake in academic discourse.

content_references.title: Document - Digital Humanities: mission accomplished? A scholarly literature analysis
content_references.snippet: Digital Humanities have been evolving throughout the parallel evolution of computers, software and networking techniques, as well as the different attitudes of the interested scholars. Since the earliest historical phases of this research field, scholars have been debating on whether it can be considered to be a new academic discipline and whether it is revolutionary in nature. About twenty years ago, the early denotation of Humanities Computing evolved to the present one, and deep changes intervened in digital information technologies, as well as in their humanities applications. content_references.title: Debates in the Digital Humanities 2023 | Debates in the Digital Humanities
content_references.snippet: Where do the digital humanities stand in 2023? Debates in the Digital Humanities 2023 presents a state-of-the-field vision of digital humanities amid rising social, political, economic, and environmental crises; a global pandemic; and the deepening of austerity regimes in U.S. higher education. Providing a look not just at where DH stands but also where it is going, this fourth volume in the Debates in the Digital Humanities series features both established scholars and emerging voices pushing the field’s boundaries, asking thorny questions, and providing space for practitioners to bring to the fore their research and their hopes for future directions in the field. content_references.title: About the Department of Digital Humanities | Department of Digital Humanities | King’s College London
content_references.snippet: King's College London has a long tradition of research in the digital humanities, going back to the early 1970s. The Department for Digital Humanities started as the 'Centre for Computing in the Humanities' in 1992. The Department has been highly influential in areas of digital information management and digital research methods, and today its expertise in digital archives and libraries is still in high demand.

content_references.title: Emerging Job Profiles for DH Graduates: a CLARIN-DARIAH Project
content_references.snippet: This poster, submitted at the CLARIN Bazaar 2024, presents the first outputs of a CLARIN-DARIAH project: Emerging Job Profiles for DH Graduates: Bridging Gaps between Industry & Education. Surveys and interviews with DH master's degree coordinators and alumni, as well as the last workshops held in Budapest and Lisbon, allow us to present an overview of best practices for bridging the gaps between education and industries. It is part of an important long-term initiative to improve collaboration between industry, cultural heritage institutions, and academia (specifically taught postgraduate DH degrees) in the framework of CLARIN and DARIAH research infrastructures.

content_references.snippet: Where do the digital humanities stand in 2023? content_references.title: Document - Digital Humanities: mission accomplished? A scholarly literature analysis
content_references.snippet: Digital Humanities have been evolving throughout the parallel evolution of computers, software and networking techniques, as well as the different attitudes of the interested scholars. Since the earliest historical phases of this research field, scholars have been debating on whether it can be considered to be a new academic discipline and whether it is revolutionary in nature. About twenty years ago, the early denotation of Humanities Computing evolved to the present one, and deep changes intervened in digital information technologies, as well as in their humanities applications. This paper accounts for the relevant scholarly debate, distinguishing between the early period and

Today, nearly all the scholars make use of information technology. This does not mean that all of them have become digital scholars. A historian, for example, who uses informatics for the quantitative aspects of their research, probably does not feel to be a ‘digital historian’, or a ‘digital humanist’. Despite the current aspirations to reach post-disciplinarity, individual disciplines are still alive and effective, even though their mutual boundaries are becoming less rigid, and keep absorbing the relevant technological innovations as they always did. DH, in turn, can be

The disciplinary status of DH has always been the object of a lively debate, giving rise to a host of specific connotations, such as inter-discipline or post-discipline, on whose meanings not all the proposers agree. Compare, for example, the positions expressed by McCarty (1999) and Burnard (1999) to the recent analyses by Darbellay (2019) and Klaassen (2020). The launch of official curricula in DH contributes to corroborate the position, shared by many, that DH is rightfully an established discipline. content_references.snippet: This article explores the transformative impact of ChatGPT, a Generative Pre- trained Transformers model, on humanities methodologies and its integration into a digital humanities (DH) course. The advent of ChatGPT enhances the capacity of people without coding experience to acquire, process, analyse and interpret art historical data, fostering a unique blend of generative AI development and humanistic inquiries. The article presents pedagogical experiences in incorporating ChatGPT, into a digital humanities course, with a focus on learning prompt engineering, a vital skill in handling art historical data. The risk of losing (analogue) data dates back to before digitisation and care was reinforced for example through transfer of data onto magnetic strips before computer memory storage [Borghoff et al. 2006]. content_references.title: | Vanderbilt University
content_references.snippet: The Center for Digital Humanities at Vanderbilt aims to create a flourishing environment for innovative exploration at the intersection of digital technology and humanities research by providing learning experiences, project support, and opportunities for interdisciplinary collaboration. We are open to undergraduates, faculty, staff, doctoral students, postdocs, and the greater Nashville DH community. We promote public scholarship and partnership-building, and we serve as a point of contact for our members, connecting humanities researchers with partners at other institutions, with synergistic colleagues across campus, or within support areas like the libraries.

content_references.title: Debates in the Digital Humanities 2023 | Debates in the Digital Humanities
content_references.snippet: Where do the digital humanities stand in 2023? Debates in the Digital Humanities 2023 presents a state-of-the-field vision of digital humanities amid rising social, political, economic, and environmental crises; a global pandemic; and the deepening of austerity regimes in U.S. higher education. Providing a look not just at where DH stands but also where it is going, this fourth volume in the Debates in the Digital Humanities series features both established scholars and emerging voices pushing the field’s boundaries, asking thorny questions, and providing space for practitioners to bring to the fore their research and their hopes for future directions in the field. content_references.title:
DHQ: Digital Humanities Quarterly: Fading Away... The challenge of sustainability in
               digital studies
content_references.snippet: In 2011, the Manifesto for Digital Humanities has made a plea “for open access to data and metadata, which must be documented and interoperable, both technically and conceptually” [Dacos 2012]. Transdisciplinary studies published around the same time underline that “sustainability challenges require new ways of knowledge production,” recommending a collaborative approach and new scientific agencies in the academic field [Lang et al. 2012]. Without doubt, the challenge of sustainability has turned into a key concern for the field of digital humanities at large as illustrated by the theme choosen by the Digital matters (an interdisciplinary research agenda) at the University of Utah.[1]

content_references.title: Emerging Job Profiles for DH Graduates: a CLARIN-DARIAH Project
content_references.snippet: This poster, submitted at the CLARIN Bazaar 2024, presents the first outputs of a CLARIN-DARIAH project: Emerging Job Profiles for DH Graduates: Bridging Gaps between Industry & Education. Surveys and interviews with DH master's degree coordinators and alumni, as well as the last workshops held in Budapest and Lisbon, allow us to present an overview of best practices for bridging the gaps between education and industries. It is part of an important long-term initiative to improve collaboration between industry, cultural heritage institutions, and academia (specifically taught postgraduate DH degrees) in the framework of CLARIN and DARIAH research infrastructures.

content_references.title: Welcome | Western Sydney University
content_references.snippet: Digital Humanities involves the application of digital methods and techniques to Humanities research. The Digital Humanities Research Initiative (DHRI) is therefore broadly concerned with mediating between computing and humanities, and between technical and non-technical disciplines. Key challenges for digital humanities at this stage of its development as a field include articulating its research agenda as a humanistic and computing discipline; promoting and supporting fruitful interaction between computational science and the arts and humanities; linking digital humanities with new media research and media theory; and bridging between digital cultural studies and the social sciences more

content_references.title:
DHQ: Digital Humanities Quarterly: The circus we deserve? A front row look at
					the organization of the annual academic conference for the Digital
					Humanities
content_references.snippet: central occasion in the digital humanities academic calendar, and, as an international, interdisciplinary, regular, long-standing, large-scale event, it provides an ideal locus to consider various aspects of contemporary academic conference organization, and how this impacts the shape and definition of a scholarly field. Examining this annual event allows us to clarify ADHO’s policies and procedures to consider how they frame the digital humanities at large. This paper approaches the annual Digital Humanities conference via a Reflection-in-Action and Reflection-on-Action approach encompassing the experiences of various people formally involved in organizing the conference

content_references.title: Welcome | Western Sydney University
content_references.snippet: * Generations of Knowledge, a virtual reality reproduction of Parramatta (Sydney, Australia) pre-European contact; * Mapping Print, Charting Enlightenment, a project reconstructing the private and public networks of the French book trade during the eighteenth century in Europe (its foundational research project,  'The French Book Trade in Enlightenment Europe', was awarded Best Digital Resource for 2017 by the British Society for Eighteenth-Century Studies); * DomeLab, a powerful visualisation environment supported by an alliance of 15 institutions for the benefit of artistic, cultural, museological and humanities research;

content_references.title: Welcome | Western Sydney University

content_references.title: Majors and Specialisations
content_references.snippet: Digital humanities combines humanities and social science subjects with new technologies to prepare for the future work place. As a digital humanities student at The University of Adelaide, you will mix your creative talents with computer science. By blending together new technologies with communication and creativity, you will be prepared for the digital age of the future.

content_references.title: Mission & Vision | DARIAH
content_references.snippet: DARIAH's mission is to empower research communities with digital methods to create, connect and share knowledge about culture and society.

content_references.title: Emerging Job Profiles for DH Graduates: a CLARIN-DARIAH Project
content_references.snippet: This poster, submitted at the CLARIN Bazaar 2024, presents the first outputs of a CLARIN-DARIAH project: Emerging Job Profiles for DH Graduates: Bridging Gaps between Industry & Education. Surveys and interviews with DH master's degree coordinators and alumni, as well as the last workshops held in Budapest and Lisbon, allow us to present an overview of best practices for bridging the gaps between education and industries. It is part of an important long-term initiative to improve collaboration between industry, cultural heritage institutions, and academia (specifically taught postgraduate DH degrees) in the framework of CLARIN and DARIAH research infrastructures.
